stem: A client with a T6 spinal cord injury is admitted to the intensive care unit. At 16:00, the client reports a severe headache and blurred vision. Based on the data provided, which of the following interventions should the nurse implement *FIRST*?

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to at least 45 degrees.
options.feedback: Elevating the head of the bed helps to lower blood pressure and is a crucial first step in managing autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Assess for bladder distension or bowel impaction.
options.feedback: Bladder distension and bowel impaction are common triggers for autonomic dysreflexia. Assessing for these is essential for identifying and addressing the underlying cause.

options.text: Check the Foley catheter for kinks or obstruction.
options.feedback: A kinked or obstructed Foley catheter can cause bladder distension, triggering autonomic dysreflexia. Ensuring proper catheter function is a priority.

options.text: Administer hydralazine IV per physician's order.
options.feedback: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive medication that will help lower the client's dangerously high blood pressure. This is an important intervention in managing autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes after administering hydralazine.
options.feedback: Frequent blood pressure monitoring is crucial after administering hydralazine to assess its effectiveness and prevent hypotension.

options.text: Administer docusate sodium PO per the medication administration record.
options.feedback: While constipation can be a trigger for autonomic dysreflexia, addressing the immediate hypertensive crisis takes priority. Docusate is a stool softener and will take time to work.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Elevate the head of the bed to at least 45 degrees. This helps to reduce cerebral blood pressure. Assess for bladder distension or bowel impaction. These are the most common triggers for autonomic dysreflexia. Check the Foley catheter for kinks or obstruction. A full bladder can trigger autonomic dysreflexia. Administer hydralazine IV per physician's order. This medication is an antihypertensive and will help lower the blood pressure. Monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes after administering hydralazine. Frequent monitoring is essential to assess the effectiveness of the intervention and prevent hypotension.
rationale.incorrect: Administer docusate sodium PO per the medication administration record. While constipation can be a trigger for autonomic dysreflexia, addressing the immediate hypertensive crisis takes priority. Docusate is a stool softener and will take time to work.

questionTrap.trap: The incorrect option focusing on docusate sodium may seem appropriate because bowel impaction is a common trigger. However, the immediate priority is to address the dangerously high blood pressure.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and the severity of the patient's symptoms. In this case, the dangerously high blood pressure necessitates immediate action to prevent stroke or other complications.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
Always address the most life-threatening problems first (ABCs).
Elevating the head of the bed is a simple and effective first step.
Hypertension and bradycardia are classic signs of autonomic dysreflexia.

itemContext.sbar: S: Robert Jameson, a 42-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury from a motorcycle accident two years ago, was admitted at 15:00 for suspected autonomic dysreflexia. He reports a throbbing headache and blurred vision. B: Patient has a history of recurrent UTIs. He manages his bowel program independently at home. Last BM was two days ago. A: At 16:00, BP is 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm. Skin is flushed above the injury level and pale below. Patient is diaphoretic. Patient reports feeling anxious. O: Continuous cardiac monitoring, SpO2 98% on room air. Foley catheter in place, draining clear yellow urine. Neurological assessment reveals no new deficits. Currently awaiting lab results. Orders include PRN hydralazine for SBP > 180. Prepare for possible bowel disimpaction.
